docs.snippet: Right now, after more than 50 fashion shows, New York Fashion Week delirium is setting in. This is when we turn to the wisdom of fashion critics to help us make sense of it all. This morning we read through Suzy Menkes's reporting for the Internat...
docs.lead_paragraph: Right now, after more than 50 fashion shows, New York Fashion Week delirium is setting in. This is when we turn to the wisdom of fashion critics to help us make sense of it all. This morning we read through Suzy Menkes's reporting for the International Herald Tribune. (Suzy, as you know, is also a columnist for T Magazine.) By the time we publish this, she will have written more. But not to worry, we'll keep you updated, and, hopefully, maintain everyone's sanity in the process.

docs.snippet: From left: Lawrence Clayton as Jesus, David Bedella as Satan and Harvey Keitel as Jerry in "Jerry Springer: The Opera" (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times) I saw "Jerry Springer: The Opera" when it was playing in London's West End. It was one of the...
docs.lead_paragraph: I saw "Jerry Springer: The Opera" when it was playing in London's West End. It was one of the most exhilarating evenings of theater I've experienced in recent years. So I was delighted when Ben Brantley raved about a New York production that had a limited run of two performances last week. "Remarkable," Brantley said, "spectacularly inventive," "celestial." At the end of his review, Brantley pleaded for some producer to open "Springer" on Broadway so that more people would be able to see it. I'm not sure that's going to happen.

docs.snippet: Vanity Fair decides not to hold its annual Oscar bash, and does so for the right reasons....
docs.lead_paragraph: As some of you may know, Vanity Fair is pulling the plug on its post-Oscar party. As Graydon Carter, the magazine's editor, told the Bagger's colleague, Richard Perez-Pena: "There will be something sort of liberating about ordering Chinese food and watching the Oscars in bed."
docs.abstract: Vanity Fair decides not to hold its annual Oscar bash, and does so for the right reasons.

docs.lead_paragraph: Just announced by Vanity Fair: "After much consideration, and in support of the writers and everyone else affected by this strike, we have decided that this is not the appropriate year to hold our annual Oscar party. We want to congratulate all of this year's nominees and we look forward to hosting our 15th Oscar party next year."

docs.snippet: I'm glad we have a show in New York that's generating some debate-Halston, of course....
docs.lead_paragraph: I'm glad we have a show in New York that's generating some debate-Halston, of course. There's nothing in my review tomorrow about Jil Sander, though I did wonder if the tulle-veiled tweed and embroidered skirts, etc. at Herrera and Oscar started with Raf Simons' transparency collection for spring. I think the only point of comparison between Sander and Halston is that both designers had to clean house a bit with their brands, find the main points. (I hate that dreaded word DNA; I expect to find bodies.) After two or three seasons of establishing a line and his tailoring, as well as the great dresses, Simons has felt free to do more with Jil. I suspect Marco Zanini will do the same thing. The guy is smart, and not affected by the side-show dramas. And look at all the boxy, flaring and embellished jackets we've seen on the runways this week-the oversized grunge plaid at Preen, the A-line shapes at Herrera, the tweed numbers at Oscar. And who does a super-simple, sharp-shouldered, one-button jacket with a slim skirt (on Freja) and makes it look new? Mister Zanini. That was my favorite look in the show. It's all about knowing what to eliminate. I agree with Marco about the 70s context thing, though I looked at it differently in the review. Halson was not about the furnishings; he was about the architecture: line and cut, and color for visual impact and warmth. So what was Liza M. doing in the front row? Why do the new owners feel they have to sell Halston by telling the history? It's such an old approach.
docs.abstract: I'm glad we have a show in New York that's generating some debate-Halston, of course.
